An epitaph on the little Erotion on whom Epp⁴ v. 36, 37 were written. The poet commends her tomb to the care of his successors. At certain festivals, offerings of garlands, essences, &c. were placed on the grave, as

Here lies Erotion in the shade Of foliage planted newly. In her sixth winter did she fade,

Cut off by fate unduly.

Thou, whosoe’er thou be, to whom Ere long these fields I render, The annual offerings at her tomb

Discharge 3 they are but slender.

So, son succeeding sire, from thee No victims death shall borrowz But on thy land this stone shall be
